ticket.title: Rails3 - accepts_nested_attributes_for reject_if option does not work.
ticket.original-body:
@@@
class Project < ActiveRecord::Base has_many :tasks accepts_nested_attributes_for :tasks, :reject_if => proc { |attributes| true } # Always reject : just to prove the case. end
class Task < ActiveRecord::Base belongs_to :project end
p = Project.create!(:name => "project") p.tasks.create!(:name => "1") p.tasks.create!(:name => "2")
p.reload
p.attributes = { "tasks_attributes" => { "0" => {"name"=>"new name", "_destroy"=>"0", "id"=> p.tasks.first.id}, } }
p.tasks => [#<Task id: 1, project_id: 1, name: "new name", created_at: "2010-09-08 08:26:49", updated_at: "2010-09-08 08:26:49">, #<Task id: 2, project_id: 1, name: "2", created_at: "2010-09-08 08:26:49", updated_at: "2010-09-08 08:26:49">] @@@
The task name is changed but it should not be due to reject_if proc.
This is on Rails 3.0.0
ticket.latest-body:
@@@
class Project < ActiveRecord::Base has_many :tasks accepts_nested_attributes_for :tasks, :reject_if => proc { |attributes| true } # Always reject : just to prove the case. end
class Task < ActiveRecord::Base belongs_to :project end
p = Project.create!(:name => "project") p.tasks.create!(:name => "1") p.tasks.create!(:name => "2")
p.reload
p.attributes = { "tasks_attributes" => { "0" => {"name"=>"new name", "_destroy"=>"0", "id"=> p.tasks.first.id}, } }
p.tasks => [#<Task id: 1, project_id: 1, name: "new name", created_at: "2010-09-08 08:26:49", updated_at: "2010-09-08 08:26:49">, #<Task id: 2, project_id: 1, name: "2", created_at: "2010-09-08 08:26:49", updated_at: "2010-09-08 08:26:49">] @@@
The task name is changed but it should not be due to reject_if proc.
This is on Rails 3.0.0
ticket.original-body-html:
class Project < ActiveRecord::Base
  has_many :tasks
  accepts_nested_attributes_for :tasks, :reject_if => proc { |attributes| true } # Always reject : just to prove the case.
end

class Task < ActiveRecord::Base
  belongs_to :project
end

p = Project.create!(:name => "project")
p.tasks.create!(:name => "1")
p.tasks.create!(:name => "2")

p.reload

p.attributes = {
  "tasks_attributes" => {
    "0" => {"name"=>"new name", "_destroy"=>"0", "id"=> p.tasks.first.id},
  }
}

p.tasks
 => [#<Task id: 1, project_id: 1, name: "new name", created_at: "2010-09-08 08:26:49", updated_at: "2010-09-08 08:26:49">, #<Task id: 2, project_id: 1, name: "2", created_at: "2010-09-08 08:26:49", updated_at: "2010-09-08 08:26:49">]

The task name is changed but it should not be due to reject_if proc.

This is on Rails 3.0.0

version.body:
@@@
class Project < ActiveRecord::Base has_many :tasks accepts_nested_attributes_for :tasks, :reject_if => proc { |attributes| true } # Always reject : just to prove the case. end
class Task < ActiveRecord::Base belongs_to :project end
p = Project.create!(:name => "project") p.tasks.create!(:name => "1") p.tasks.create!(:name => "2")
p.reload
p.attributes = { "tasks_attributes" => { "0" => {"name"=>"new name", "_destroy"=>"0", "id"=> p.tasks.first.id}, } }
p.tasks => [#<Task id: 1, project_id: 1, name: "new name", created_at: "2010-09-08 08:26:49", updated_at: "2010-09-08 08:26:49">, #<Task id: 2, project_id: 1, name: "2", created_at: "2010-09-08 08:26:49", updated_at: "2010-09-08 08:26:49">] @@@

version.body-html:
class Project < ActiveRecord::Base
  has_many :tasks
  accepts_nested_attributes_for :tasks, :reject_if => proc { |attributes| true } # Always reject : just to prove the case.
end

class Task < ActiveRecord::Base
  belongs_to :project
end

p = Project.create!(:name => "project")
p.tasks.create!(:name => "1")
p.tasks.create!(:name => "2")

p.reload

p.attributes = {
  "tasks_attributes" => {
    "0" => {"name"=>"new name", "_destroy"=>"0", "id"=> p.tasks.first.id},
  }
}

p.tasks
 => [#<Task id: 1, project_id: 1, name: "new name", created_at: "2010-09-08 08:26:49", updated_at: "2010-09-08 08:26:49">, #<Task id: 2, project_id: 1, name: "2", created_at: "2010-09-08 08:26:49", updated_at: "2010-09-08 08:26:49">]

The task name is changed but it should not be due to reject_if proc.

This is on Rails 3.0.0
version.title: Rails3 - accepts_nested_attributes_for reject_if option does not work.

version.body:
Hmm, it's behaviour seems weird although I might be missing something as well.
I tried your example and editing a tasks attributes seems to work, adding a new one does not:
@@@ ruby ruby-1.9.2-p0 > p = Project.create!(:name => 'project') => #<Project id: 3, name: "project", created_at: "2010-09-08 10:35:31", updated_at: "2010-09-08 10:35:31"> ruby-1.9.2-p0 > p.tasks.create!(:name => 'task 1') => #<Task id: 4, name: "task 1", project_id: 3, created_at: "2010-09-08 10:35:39", updated_at: "2010-09-08 10:35:39"> ruby-1.9.2-p0 > p.tasks_attributes = [ { :id => 4, :name => 'changed'} ] => [{:id=>4, :name=>"changed"}] ruby-1.9.2-p0 > p.save => true ruby-1.9.2-p0 > p.tasks => [#<Task id: 4, name: "changed", project_id: 3, created_at: "2010-09-08 10:35:39", updated_at: "2010-09-08 10:36:06">] ruby-1.9.2-p0 > p.tasks_attributes = [ { :name => 'new task' } ] => [{:id=>5, :name=>"new task"}] ruby-1.9.2-p0 > p.save => true ruby-1.9.2-p0 > p.tasks => [#<Task id: 4, name: "changed", project_id: 3, created_at: "2010-09-08 10:35:39", updated_at: "2010-09-08 10:36:06">] ruby-1.9.2-p0 > @@@
version.body-html:
Hmm, it's behaviour seems weird although I might be missing something as well.

I tried your example and editing a tasks attributes seems to work, adding a new one does not:

ruby-1.9.2-p0 > p = Project.create!(:name => 'project')
 => #<Project id: 3, name: "project", created_at: "2010-09-08 10:35:31", updated_at: "2010-09-08 10:35:31"> 
ruby-1.9.2-p0 > p.tasks.create!(:name => 'task 1')
 => #<Task id: 4, name: "task 1", project_id: 3, created_at: "2010-09-08 10:35:39", updated_at: "2010-09-08 10:35:39"> 
ruby-1.9.2-p0 > p.tasks_attributes = [ { :id => 4, :name => 'changed'} ]
 => [{:id=>4, :name=>"changed"}] 
ruby-1.9.2-p0 > p.save
 => true 
ruby-1.9.2-p0 > p.tasks
 => [#<Task id: 4, name: "changed", project_id: 3, created_at: "2010-09-08 10:35:39", updated_at: "2010-09-08 10:36:06">] 
ruby-1.9.2-p0 > p.tasks_attributes = [ { :name => 'new task' } ]
 => [{:id=>5, :name=>"new task"}] 
ruby-1.9.2-p0 > p.save
 => true 
ruby-1.9.2-p0 > p.tasks
 => [#<Task id: 4, name: "changed", project_id: 3, created_at: "2010-09-08 10:35:39", updated_at: "2010-09-08 10:36:06">] 
ruby-1.9.2-p0 >
version.title: Rails3 - accepts_nested_attributes_for reject_if option does not work.

version.body-html:
@Mark you are right. While creating a new record reject_if is being respected but while updating it was being ignored.

Attached is a patch with test.

Please try this patch and see if it works.
version.title: Rails3 - accepts_nested_attributes_for reject_if option does not work.

version.body: Can someone verify my patch and provide comments. Thanks.
version.body-html: Can someone verify my patch and provide comments. Thanks.
version.title: Rails3 - accepts_nested_attributes_for reject_if option does not work.

version.body:
Hi Neeraj,
Your patch works well for me. I ran the tests and they pass.
I also ran your patch against the OP code and the patch rejects the name change on the task, just as it is supposed to.
Thanks
+1
version.body-html:
Hi Neeraj,

Your patch works well for me. I ran the tests and they pass.

I also ran your patch against the OP code and the patch rejects the name change on the task, just as it is supposed to.

Thanks

+1

version.title: Rails3 - accepts_nested_attributes_for reject_if option does not work.

version.body:
Hi there. Though I'm using rails-3.0.3 (and of course activerecord-3.0.3) I'm facing this very same issue, exactly same behaviour. FTR, here's my sources:
# app/models/invoice.rb class Invoice < ActiveRecord::Base attr_accessible :tax, :discount, :modifier, :paid, :issue_date, :payment_date, :description, :items_attributes has_many :items, :class_name => 'InvoiceItem', :dependent => :destroy accepts_nested_attributes_for :items, :reject_if => proc { |a| a[:description].blank? }, :allow_destroy => true end
# app/models/invoice_item.rb class InvoiceItem < ActiveRecord::Base attr_accessible :price, :discount, :description belongs_to :invoice end
I could verify that the :reject_if is honoured when creating a new Invoice, while it's not when updating an existing one.
version.body-html:
Hi there. Though I'm using rails-3.0.3 (and of course activerecord-3.0.3) I'm facing this very same issue, exactly same behaviour. FTR, here's my sources:

app/models/invoice.rb

class Invoice < ActiveRecord::Base

attr_accessible :tax, :discount, :modifier, :paid, :issue_date, :payment_date, :description, :items_attributes
has_many :items, :class_name => 'InvoiceItem', :dependent => :destroy
accepts_nested_attributes_for :items, :reject_if => proc { |a| a[:description].blank? }, :allow_destroy => true

end

app/models/invoice_item.rb

class InvoiceItem < ActiveRecord::Base

attr_accessible :price, :discount, :description
belongs_to :invoice

end

I could verify that the :reject_if is honoured when creating a new Invoice, while it's not when updating an existing one.
version.title: Rails3 - accepts_nested_attributes_for reject_if option does not work.

version.body: The proc (or symbol to a method) given to an accept_nested_attributes_for method for a has_one association never runs (for me, on Rails 3.0.3). Did anyone give that one a test?
version.body-html: The proc (or symbol to a method) given to an accept_nested_attributes_for method for a has_one association never runs (for me, on Rails 3.0.3). Did anyone give that one a test?
version.title: Rails3 - accepts_nested_attributes_for reject_if option does not work.

version.body: @Dave - could you write a failing test case ?
version.body-html: @Dave - could you write a failing test case ?
version.title: Rails3 - accepts_nested_attributes_for reject_if option does not work.
